title: Does the free will defence successfully solve the problem of evil? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, Free Will Defence does not solve the problem of moral evil. Free Will Defence (FWD) seems to be the most popular “solution” to the problem of evil but this popularity is not warranted because FWD has problems. To put it shortly: there’s no logical reason for why God couldn’t have created the world in such a way that no one wants to do evil. The key word here is “logical” because God is usually understood as a being who can do anything and everything that is logically possible. God is also understood as perfectly benevolent. Therefore, if God could have created humankind in this manner, then he should have done so given that he is perfectly benevolent. But this is not the case. And it seems clear that God could have created humankind in this manner. What follows is an argument to this conclusion. There’s no necessity for most of us to commit any evil deed such as murder, rape or robbery. This is an obvious empirical fact. But FWD assumes that there’s a logical necessity for some people to commit these deeds. Where does this logical necessity come from? I’ve never seen anyone explain this to me in a convincing manner. If some (actually most) people are capable of avoiding evil deeds, why would it be impossible for all of us to be able to avoid them? I can see no plausible reason for why some people would be forced by logical necessity to commit evil acts, but this is precisely what Free Will Defence requires to “solve” the problem of evil. So to summarize: the basic problem with Free Will Defence is that there’s no logical reason for why God couldn’t have created the world in such a way that every human being, by their own free will, wants to avoid evil deeds. Most people are capable of this so there’s no obvious logical necessity for some people to commit them. Until someone can give a valid logical reason for why at least one person must commit evil deeds for free will to exist, then the Free Will Defence is not feasible and cannot be used to solve the problem of evil.

No, absolutely not. An obvious outcome is that there still exists a sub-area in theology known as theodicy that aims to solve the problem of evil. (If the problem of evil is already successfully solved, I don’t see the need for such a subject to continue haunting us.) The reason why the free will defense seems to be irrefutable is that people generally have a wrong impression that if an argument has a good premise (in this case, free will), then it is a good argument, which is not true. An argument is only sound when the logic is valid and the premise is good; what theists generally fail to properly show is how this premise that people have free will leads to the conclusion that a good God can coexist with evil in the world. Firstly, the problem of evil generally is stated as: If an omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent God exists, then evil does not.Evil exists.Therefore, an omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent God does not exist.For instance, God, all-powerful and all-merciful, must have the ability and the will to stop the Holocaust from happening, yet the Holocaust happened; therefore God does not exist. The free will defense, in its commonest form, goes like: The omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent God gave people free wills.Free will is a source of both good and evil.Therefore, evil can co-exist with an omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent God.So, to respond to the Holocaust case, theodicists will likely argue that the Holocaust was done by the free wills of mankind, which, as they think, was none of God’s business. I shall let go the question of whether an omniscient God can co-exist with free will and the problem of non-human evil such as the existence of natural disasters, not really because they are not important, but because I disagree with the theodicists’ logic that evils caused by free wills are compatible with an omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent God. The implicit assumption made in the logic above is that when the free wills of people manifest in reality, that is, when people have evil thoughts and hence conduct those thoughts as actions, God should still be silent, which is a precise re-statement of the problem of evil. Consider again the case of the Holocaust. I agree that it was a human tragedy and thus an evil from free will. However, does that mean that God couldn’t do anything about it? For example, when the Nazi were about to commence a slaughter in a Jewish community, and God, through some means, transported the residents to a safer place, say the US, would anybody’s free will be affected? Perhaps the evil thoughts of people were not stoppable by God for them to have free wills, but why should the evil consequences also be not stoppable by God? The premise that people have free wills cannot properly lead to the conclusion that the good God should bear with the bad actions of them. Next time, if you hear an apologist saying “because God gave us free will”, ask them to elaborate that sentence, and you’ll see the problem. Note: This can actually go back to the old question of why God doesn’t do miracles any more; in the Biblical stories, for example, when Moses and the Israelite faced the Red Sea, God opened the waters for them, yet in the 20th century, a similar or even more serious crisis happened to His very chosen people, and He decided to be blind about it.

Firstly, I think the question can be improved by differentiating between defense and response. A defense only needs to be deployed in the event of a perceived or actual offense. The "problem of evil" is not an attack, but a philosophical speculation that seemingly contradicts with the notional belief of a loving God, as maintained by Christianity. Secondly, evil is not necessarily a problem. Certainly evil can be problematic, but in and of itself it is not a problem. In Christianity it is a reality, not a problem. If the clarified questions is "Is Free Will a justifiable/adequate response to the existence of evil?" I think the answer is: No, the doctrine of Free Will does not help address the co-existence of evil with that of a loving God. The mythic concept of Satan takes care of that issue. Free Will certainly supplements the fulness of understanding, but it should never be deployed in attempt to solve the existence of evil. Actually, there is nothing to solve; not all dichotomies need to be justified.

No it does not and i can't see how it became such a popular ''answer''. Free will does not apply to nature. The cause of most of our problems are not man made. Disease, famine, and natural disasters. They have no will, and they are not evil either but cause suffering.  If however by evil you mean only what people do to each other because they are bad people, the answer is still No. Arguing that god is all good and all powerful, while not stopping rapists and murderers makes no sense. God knew exactly what he was creating and what it would become. He knew at creation in detail what would happen to every victim of child abuse and torture. He chose to let it happen anyway. God is ultimately responsible for his creation. He created faulty humans and demanded they behave and play nice. That is at best naive. Cruel even.

Free will is a partial solution to the Problem of Evil, and it is the most foundational. Free will must be part of the picture, because without it God is directly responsible for evil that occurs. By creating free agents, God created the possibility for evil to be done. However, He is not culpable for the free actions taken by the free agents He created. Nevertheless, it's not likely that free will can be the only explanation for the existence of all suffering, since there is natural evil like tornadoes that free agents are not likely the cause of. I think in these cases we need to think of other possible reasons why God would permit suffering. I have an in-depth article I developed years ago that addresses some of these - http://www.skepticalchristian.com/problemofevil.htm Alvin Plantinga, however, did point out that natural evil could be caused by the free will choices of angels or other beings. In this case free will could be a full answer to the Problem of Evil. However, it would be less satisfying of an answer in because it seems implausible or silly to take this route to answer the argument.

Q. Does Free will defense successfully solve the Problem of evil (PoE)?  (1) Firstly, what’s the PoE? If God exists, is God entirely good, or partially good and partially evil?How can you tell?If God is entirely good, where does the evil of the world come from?Did God create it?How could evil come from an entirely good thing?If God didn’t create evil, why does God allow it to exist?(2) There’re multiple responses to the PoE. The most famous is the “Free Will Defense”. (3) ‘Free Will’ Defense (3a) Simply… There is evil in the world.Evil enters the world through human choice.Free Will is so important to God that God allows evil for its sake.It would be lame if God allows Free Will, and then, as and when inconvenient, intervenes to mitigate evil’s negative effects, or ‘switches off’ Free Will momentarily. Either there’s Free Will, or there isn’t.(3b) We return to this Quora question. Does Free Will Defense successfully solve the PoE? Short answer: By the above frameset, anddisregarding other competing responses,yes.All the other responses are relative to a specific frameset.(4) Other PoE Responses (4a) The following reponses depart from the notion of God. God doesn’t exist.God exists, but is partially evil.God is good, but not omnipotent. So, evil creeps into the world despite God’s goodness and love.There’s a good divine force, but an evil one as well, strong enough to compete with God’s will. Our world is a battleground between them.(4b) There’s no ‘evil’. Only ‘absence of good’. Consider this analogy. There’s light and there’s darkness. There can be 2 different perspectives. Intuitively, there’re 2 things: light and darkness.Somewhat less intuitively, there’s only one thing: light. Hence, there’s ‘light’ and ‘absence of light’.Thus, There is ‘good’.There’s ‘absence of good’.There’s no such thing as ‘evil’.Another analogy, this time, more personal. You injured yourself.You’ve a wound.Your wound heals.You no longer have a wound.Your wound didn’t ‘go anywhere’. There’s just ‘an absence of wound’ on you. (Similarly, for ‘evil’, it doesn’t ‘go anywhere’.)Thus, Evil is not real.It’s only the ‘absence of good’.You fall into evil and suffering because God made you from nothing.When you move away from God’s goodness, you tend to return to nothing.(4c) Theodicy Justification of God. God allows evil because suffering is necessary for human development. Without the negative, we can’t appreciate the positive. Some elements of human greatness can only be achieved through suffering, strife and loss. The basic idea is that even though there’s evil and suffering, this is still the best of all possible worlds. Good outweighs evil in the world. But, this is arguable. Go ask people who face discrimination all their life. Is God A White Racist? (4d) Suffering is a Divine Punishment For Sin What about the suffering of innocent individuals? Terminally ill infants? Animals burned alive in forest fires? (5) This Quora answer merely presents the common PoE responses, and their underlying framesets, dispassionately. It does not suggest that any response is superior to another. (5) Divine Foreknowledge If you’ve Free Will, does God know what you will choose?If God doesn’t know what you choose, why not, if God is omniscient and omnipotent?If God does know what you’ll choose, why does he let you choose to do bad things?If God let’s you do bad things, when he could’ve stopped you, is it fair to punish you for doing what he could’ve stopped?Or, if it’s fair to punish you for your intention alone, why not stop you from doing something, and just punish you for what you would have done?

Yes if it comes to the deductive version of the problem - or at least that seems to be the conclusion of the majority of modern philosophers of religion, theists and atheists alike, since Alvin Plantinga published his version of the free will defense in The Nature of Necessity. Now in what comes the the inductive version, I'm not sure if the Free Will Defense applies to it. Fact is that most atheist philosophers of religion that still defend a problem of evil nowadays do it in the inductive version and, therefore, even if the defense is valid for that version of the problem, it doesn't seem to have been as successful as it was with the deductive version.

Free will is basically a right to choose and the Bible uses it almost exclusively in the New Testament to denote a person's ability to repent.  There are other choices in life, however, each basically surmounting to the choice between following God's ways vs. any other way, including our own.  God is good, therefore He is the author and sustainer of what is good.  Evil on the other hand is anything contrary to God's ways; even His very attributes and desires.  That is the very nature of what sin is: anything and everything that is or is done in opposition to God.  Free Will is simply the ability to choose a or b.
